title: USB Multiboot Several Windows XP versions plus

forumNotes.author: darkman738
forumNotes.content:
Sorry if this has been asked, but I did not see this particular version of this question asked in the forums, although I could have missed it.  

I am looking to create a multiboot USB where I can boot to and install multiple versions of Windows XP (i.e. Home SP1 \& SP3, Pro SP1 \& SP3, MCE SP1 \& MCE SP3) and some additional ISO's that are linux based (i.e. gparted, Ophcrack ect). So no know asks, yes the redundancy is necessary, SP2 and up keys were changed, and any OEM sticker on a computer with a blue background (SP0/SP1) won't install with an SP2/SP3 disk.   

As far as I can tell this has a couple problems:  

1) I can use syslinux and load the ISO's but this requires a FAT32 file system which is quite slow on the read/write, esp with multiple files. I am also getting an error with this, but I think I may have learned what the problem is here. I could extract and chainload the the install, but I think that there is a problem with not having the install files in the root dir of the drive, which can't happen with 6 versions of the same OS.  

2) All the tutorials I find that allow for NTFS FS assume a single copy of Windows (i.e. Home SP3) with no way to add a additional version, and aren't MultiBoot  

Currently I have a working version loading everything I need except the Windows installers with a neat tool from [here](http://www.pendrivelinux.com/boot-multiple-iso-from-usb-multiboot-usb/ "External link").   

My ideal solution would be extracting the ISO's and loading them from a directory on the drive (/Windows_Installers/WinXP_Home_SP1/) To allow me to slipstream additional drivers, patches, and software on-the-fly, but I can just as well unpack and repack an ISO, just not in the field.  

Anyone have a suggestion? Something I missed? The FS does matter as I am trying to reduce the amount of time I spend in front of the unit restoring.  

Thanks in advance.

forumNotes.author: cdob
forumNotes.content:
> but it still looks like there is the limitation of a Fat32 FS
Which XP installation approach is limited to FAT32?  
All sticky arroaches work at NTFS. [http://www.msfn.org/...ndows-from-usb/](http://www.msfn.org/board/forum/157-install-windows-from-usb/ "External link")  

> as it is using G4D
What's G4D?  
Grub4dos works fine at FAT12, FAT16, FAT32 and NTFS (up to windows 7).  

Use a proper application to partition and format USB drive as you like.   
Add XP installation files.  

Slow FAT32 has been reported years ago.  
[http://www.msfn.org/...post__p__699197](http://www.msfn.org/board/topic/61384-how-to-bootinstall-from-usb-key/page__view__findpost__p__699197 "External link")  

Authors recommned NTFS instead of FAT32.  
Example [http://www.msfn.org/...post__p__731488](http://www.msfn.org/board/topic/111406-how-to-install-xp-from-usb/page__view__findpost__p__731488 "External link")  
> - Format the USB-Drive with FAT or NTFS. Note: FAT32 is very SLOW for installing XP

I prefer a ISO image file loaded to RAM.  
That's one continuous read from USB drive to RAM.   
Single files are copied from RAM to hard disk. File access time is very fast at RAM.

> Did I miss something?
Did you read sticky at [http://www.msfn.org/...ndows-from-usb/](http://www.msfn.org/board/forum/157-install-windows-from-usb/ "External link") ?  

USB_MultiBoot.cmd dosn't mount a ISO at all.  

WinSetupFromUSB mount a samll ISO file to RAM, size about 1mb.  
Can you spare ONE mb to a RAM disk?  

Or create a new ISO image, sort basic installation files in front.  
RAM load part of a ISO image.   

Or create a PE, use flat files.   
Boot this PE. And install XP.
